Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2009 07:23AM Poppy wrote: Hi Patti, I'm not Stage IV but I have been a child who lost my father too soon. My dad kept everything. Some stuff was in the attic (college photos, a favorite shirt), some in his office (the bobblehead Snoopy from the 70's) and some was stuff I saw every day. When I was a kid, he smoked a pipe. He had tons of pipes. I have them - but the thing I keep out is the leather tobacco container. Even after all of these years, if I open it, I smell the tobacco he smoked when I was a kid. I have a lot of his things and a lot is in storage, but over the years I have sussed out the precious items that keep his memory alive and those things are a part of my home. His old polo shirt that he did yard work in is one of my favorite "junky shirts" to wear. I can't offer advice on what to do, only that you might have no idea what is meaningful to your family. I have an old jelly glass with Bugs Bunny on it and my husband has claimed it as his own. He says he can see me running around with it as a kid. I know when I'm gone, that glass will always remind him of me but that's only b/c he told me! Otherwise, it might've gone in the Goodwill pile long ago. At 5 and 10, your boys are old enough to tell you what reminds them of you. You could ask them what items, scents, vacations, etc... they think of when they think of you.  If a certain trip or occasion jumps out as special to one of them, you could maybe frame a picture from that time for that child. I don't know the answer, but I just didn't want you to overlook the seemingly unimportant things that might just be the most valuable. Hugs Erica

Posts.Content: Poppy wrote: Sorry if this has been posted before but this story was so amazing I wanted to share. I was watching 60 Minutes tonight while waiting for Big Brother to come on (CBS was running late) and thankfully so. There was the most interesting story! This might be on CBS.com but I didn't check. This is a gross summary of the story but I swear I was almost in tears watching it. There's this man who is fighting terminal cancer (lymphoma I think) and he built radios as a kid. He knew that radio waves heat metal but are safe to people. So one night - in a chemo induced state - he started banging around in the kitchen with the pots and pans. His poor wife thought he'd lost it but he ended up building something that they say is working! Basically they inject gold particles into a tumor and the metal binds to the tumor but not normal cells. Then they shoot radio waves at the tumor and it kills it but doesn't do anything to the healthy cells. I guess the radio waves heat the metal (which cooks the cancer cells but no others). Can you imagine being able to treat cancer as easily as that?!!! It was so amazing. They said it'll probably be 4 years before they have the means to treat metastatic cancer but HELLO, that is so simple and 4 years is not that long. For metastatic cancer they showed a computer model of injecting a bazillion teeny tiny gold particles into the bloodstream. The gold finds the tumor cells and binds only to them. Then - radio waves cook the cells. Right now MD Anderson and one other research hospital are working with this machine and I hope they can get the injection stuff worked out quickly...they say it will treat (or cure supposedly) all kinds of cancer. AMAZING. Hopefully this poor man will live long enough to see his machine in action! Hugs Erica Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2008 01:59AM Poppy wrote: Hi Freaked, I was dx with invasive and DCIS April 2005. What you're feeling is completely normal and I encourage you to come to this site and ask every question and post every fear! Check the chemo threads and see if there's one for the month you will start chemo. If there isn't, start one! There will be women who will be going through the same stuff at the same time and it's a wonderful support (and maybe you'll make some lifelong friends). The BC diagnosis is so overwhelming... just remember that the surgeries and treatments are there to save your life. When I was going through A/C-T chemo I thought it would never end. Now, over 3 years since I finished treatment, it's a distant memory. I also encourage you not to search the internet for answers. The internet is great, but it's a scary and sometimes misinformed place. BCO is a safe place to ask the questions. If you want more information about a drug or information that someone here gives you, then go to the internet. Hang in there... what surgery will you be having? There are a lot of things you can do to make post-surgery more comfortable and the ladies here know them all! xoxo
